'''''Trogia venenata''''',<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Yang, Z. L. |author2=Li, Y. C. |author3=Tang, L. P. |author4=Shi, G. Q. |author5=Zeng, G. | title = ''Trogia venenata'' (Agaricales), a novel poisonous species which has caused hundreds of deaths in southwestern China | journal = Mycological Progress | year = 2012 | volume = 11 | issue = 4 | pages = 937–945 | doi = 10.1007/s11557-012-0809-y }}</ref> also known as the '''little white mushroom''',<ref>{{cite web
|url         = http://www.australiangeographic.com.au/journal/tiny-toxic-mushrooms-kill-hundreds-in-china.htm | title = Toxic mushrooms kill hundreds in China | last = Tran | first = T. | date = 14 July 2010 | website = Australian Geographic | quote = Now, after a five-year investigation, an elite investigative unit from China's Centre for Disease Control and Prevention believes it has pinpointed the cause: an innocuous-looking small mushroom known as the little white.}}</ref> is a species of [[fungus]] in the [[Marasmiaceae]] family [[Indigenous (ecology)|indigenous]] to [[Yunnan]] province, in southwest [[China]].  Consumption is deadly for both humans and [[mouse|mice]], as the [[mushroom]] contains three toxic [[amino acid]]s.<ref name=Trogiavenenata>{{Cite journal | last1 = Zhou | first1 = Z. Y. | last2 = Shi | first2 = G. Q. | last3 = Fontaine | first3 = R. | last4 = Wei | first4 = K. | last5 = Feng | first5 = T. | last6 = Wang | first6 = F. | last7 = Wang | first7 = G. Q. | last8 = Qu | first8 = Y. | last9 = Li | first9 = Z. H. | last10 = Dong | first10 = Z. J. | last11 = Zhu | first11 = H. J. | last12 = Yang | first12 = Z. L. | last13 = Zeng | first13 = G. | last14 = Liu | first14 = J. K. | title = Evidence for the Natural Toxins from the Mushroom ''Trogia venenata'' as a Cause of Sudden Unexpected Death in Yunnan Province, China | doi = 10.1002/anie.201106502 | journal = Angewandte Chemie International Edition | year = 2012  | volume = 51 | issue = 10 | pages = 2368–2370 | pmid =  22287497| pmc = }}</ref>

This is the presumed cause of [[Yunnan sudden death syndrome]].  

In December 2012 it was announced that Dr. Xu Jianping (徐建平) has been collecting samples of ''Trogia venenata'' in Yunnan for the past three years, and his research now shows that [[barium]] (previously thought to be the cause) levels in the wild mushroom are no higher than those of common foods such as [[poultry]] and [[fish]]. {{Citation needed|date=May 2019}} 

Nonetheless, it appears the mushroom will still likely play a role. Since publication of the widely circulated 2010 Science article, no instances of Yunnan sudden death syndrome have been reported.
